titlestmt.titleproper: International Advertising Association. International Advertising Exposition exhibitor handouts
Guide to the International Advertising Association. International Advertising Exposition exhibitor handouts, 1925-1928 and undated RL.11668
titlestmt.author: Richard Collier

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-09-26 13:22:12 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: International Advertising Association. International Advertising Exposition exhibitor handouts

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History

did.abstract: Advertising trade organization founded in 1905 as Associated Advertising Clubs of America, changing its name in 1926 to International Advertising Association and in 1929 to Advertising Federation of America; the first international exposition was held in July 1928 in Detroit, Mich. Collection includes reprints, print advertisements, brochures, booklets and other printed materials handed out by participant exhibitors representing a variety of fields in the advertising and marketing industry, including apparel, direct mail, electric and neon signs, graphic art, gravure, newspapers, outdoor advertising, photolithography, telephotography, trade and women's clubs, and window show displays. Companies represented include firms from the U.S., Canada and Great Britain, including the Advertising Club of New York, AT&T, Aronsson Printing, Art Gravure, Bausch & Lomb, Capitol Machine, Chicago Daily News, Consolidated Press, Detroit Free Press, Dictaphone, Fairchild Publications, General Outdoor, Jam Handy, Mulford, National Printing & Engraving, and R.F. Heinrich. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Advertising trade organization founded in 1905 as Associated Advertising Clubs of America, changing its name in 1926 to International Advertising Association and in 1929 to Advertising Federation of America; the first international exposition was held in July 1928 in Detroit, Mich. In 1967 a merger of Advertising Federation of America and Advertising Association of the West formed the American Advertising Federation.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The International Advertising Association. International Advertising Exposition exhibitor handouts were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2007.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item], International Advertising Association. International Advertising Exposition exhibitor handouts, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2007-0152, 2007-0153, 2007-0154

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following Hartman Center collections:
J. Walter Thompson Company. Competitive Advertisements;
J. Walter Thompson Company. Corporation Vertical Files;
Outdoor Advertising Association of America Archives;
Roy Lightner Collection of Antique Advertisements;

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection includes reprints, print advertisements, brochures, booklets and other printed materials handed out by participant exhibitors representing a variety of fields in the advertising and marketing industry, including apparel, direct mail, electric and neon signs, graphic art, gravure, newspapers, outdoor advertising, photolithography, telephotography, trade and women's clubs, and window show displays. Companies represented include firms from the U.S., Canada and Great Britain, including the Advertising Club of New York, AT&T, Aronsson Printing, Art Gravure, Bausch & Lomb, Capitol Machine, Chicago Daily News, Consolidated Press, Detroit Free Press, Dictaphone, Fairchild Publications, General Outdoor, Jam Handy, Mulford, National Printing & Engraving, and R.F. Heinrich. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes: Demonstration: The "Open Sesame" to the Dealer's Window; Dramatizing the Window Display; Light vs. Motion in Window Display; Putting a Selling Plan Back of the Display; Putting More Sales-Power in Jewelry Windows; The Co-operative Idea in Window Display
